item.title: Report E-2023050334
item.description:
Report E-2023050334

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-17T03:10:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-03
  • City: SCHENECTADY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 4/03/2023 Veolia employees from the Schenectady, NY ten day intransit facility were unloading drums from a trailer into another trailer when an employee noticed that a 55-gallon steel drum leaked during the initial shipment. The leak occurred in a trailer that arrived from the Veolia, Kenmore, NY 10-day transfer location. The shipment was picked up by Veolia on 3/29/2023 and then driven to the Veolia, Schenectady office on 3/31/2023 and subsequently offloaded on 4/3/23. Employees opened the trailer on 4/3/23 and observed a 55 gallon drum containing flammable liquids was slowly leaking. The drum had a dent and small hole in it. Liquid was observed beneath the drum on the floor but did not leak out of the vehicle. The drum was overpacked into an 85 gallon salvage drum, the spill cleaned up, and transportation to the ultimate disposal facility was continued. The drum leaked about 1 gallon of a class 3 flammable liquid solution. The liquid was cleaned up with spill pads and absorbent and the lid on the drum was overpacked properly to prevent it from spilling. The duration of release is anticipated to be about 3 to 5 days and an estimated 1 gallon of flammable liquids leaked. The drum was still substantially full when the leak was discovered. No material made is outside the vehicle.

item.title: Report E-2023050331
item.description:
Report E-2023050331

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-17T03:10:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-27
  • City: TONAWANDA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On April 27, 2023, two (2) pails containing UN1263 were crushed and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted surfaces. ES personnel restacked all undamaged pails for continued shipment, then deployed granular absorbents to the release. Utilizing hand tools, all spent absorbents, damaged pails, and impacted boxes were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023050223
item.description:
Report E-2023050223

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-17T03:10:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-28
  • City: ROCHESTER
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On April 28, 2023, at 0725 ET, XPO Logistics Terminal XRC, experienced a UN1760 “Nalco EC5427A” release from a 55-gallon metal drum due to a forklift puncture. ERTS dispatched Hepaco to conduct all on site cleanup and overpacking operations. On April 28, 2023, at 1038 EST, Hepaco personnel arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released to a 4’ x 6’ area of the trailer floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was containerized into an 85-gallon poly over pack. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into a 30-gallon poly drum. All waste was left onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023040433
item.description:
Report E-2023040433

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-17T03:10:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-12
  • City: ALBANY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On April 12, 2023, at 1800 ET, XPO Logistics Terminal XAB, experienced a UN3266 “FC 509 P” release from a 5-gallon poly pail due to a forklift puncture. No soil, drains, or waterways were reported to have been impacted. ERTS dispatched Hepaco to conduct all on site cleanup activities. On April 12, 2023, at 1900 EST, Hepaco arrived on site and confirmed approximately 3-gallons of product released to a 5' x 5' area of the trailer floor and asphalt lot below due to a forklift puncture. Most of the product reportedly leaked through the trailer floor to the parking lot. The crew used a citric acid solution on the trailer floor and then deployed Oil Dri to collect the released product from both impacted areas. The damaged pail was placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. All impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were placed into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023050329
item.description:
Report E-2023050329

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-17T03:10:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-03-31
  • City: SCHENECTADY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 3/31/2023 a Veolia employee from the Newington, CT office was unloading drums into a trailer at the Veolia, Schenectady, NY ten day intransit facility when an employee noticed that a 55-gallon steel drum leaked in the transport vehicle. The shipment was picked up from the customer by Veolia on 3/31/2023 and then driven to the Veolia, Schenectady office on 3/31/2023. When the shipment arrived, a 55 gallon drum containing sodium hydroxide solid had a cover that was not secured properly. In addition there was liquid in the drum that spilled out the open lid onto the floor of the box van. The drum was sealed properly by fixing the lid so that it could continue transportation to the ultimate disposal facility. The drum leaked about 1/2 gallon of class 8 material sodium hydroxide solution. The liquid was cleaned up with spill pads and absorbent and the lid on the drum was repositioned properly to prevent it from spilling. The duration of release is anticipated to be about 3 hours and an estimated 1/2 a gallon of sodium hydroxide solution leaked. The drum was still substantially full when the leak was discovered. No material made is outside the vehicle.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The box was wet when arrived in trailer to warehouse. Package handler noticed so retrieved plastic hazmat bin to place box in. When package handler put his gloves on and placed box into bin, liquid spilled out. upon inspection saw only one gallon container had leaked a small amount of liquid. When cap was tightened. No liquid was released. DescribePack: The cap was loose on one of the plastic gallon containers. One quarter cup of liquid leaked out. The cap on the one container was tightened and no leaking took place any more. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The box was placed into a red hazmat materials bin and the cap was tightened on the plastic gallon container.

item.title: Report X-2023030357
item.description:
Report X-2023030357

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-17T03:10:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-03-01
  • City: HOLBROOK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The methanol was shipped with paper formed packaging to go around the 4x4 liter containers. This paper packaging was similar to how wine is shipped. There were cracks in the top paper form. The paper form was not solid. There were cracks in the top of the paper form. The box looked wet in the trailer at unload. The manager got gloves and a red hazmat bin. When the manager picked up the box to put into the red hazmat bin, the liquid started pouring out of the fiberboard box and into the red hazmat bin. Upon inspection, saw the 2X4 liter glass containers broken, DescribePack: The top paper form to hold the glass bottles in place had cracks in it. The paper forms were able to move and bend. The bottles were able to touch each other during transit. When the box was picked up and placed into the plastic hazmat bin, the cracked glass moved and the liquid came pouring out. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The box had already been placed into a plastic hazmat bin so the release was contained.

item.title: Report I-2023030076
item.description:
Report I-2023030076

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-02-23
  • City: JAMAICA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: LUFTHANSA CARGO, A. G.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The shipment in question was incorrectly booked by the shipper as general cargo with no mention on either documentation or in the booking that the shipment contained Lithium Metal Batteries packed with equipment UN3091 . Upon physical delivery of the cargo the physical acceptance agent failed to notice the ELM labels with UN3091 on the boxes under the clear overpack so in turn did not report the discrepancy to a supervisor or office agent. The shipment was stored in a location. Upon build up for the flight the agent that retrieved the cargo also did not notice and in turn did not report that the labels on the shipment (UN3091) did not match the paperwork. The cargo was loaded on an airline pallet and surrounded by other cargo making it impossible at that point for anyone esle to notice the labels. In turn the shipment was transported by air to Munich Germany with final dest of Inchon Korea. The shipment was stopped in Munich.

item.title: Report E-2023020099
item.description:
Report E-2023020099

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-01-07
  • City: SCHENECTADY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 1/07/2023 Veolia employees were loading drums into a trailer at the Veolia, Schenectady, NY facility when an employee inadvertently punctured a 55 gallon plastic drum when it was being loaded on a trailer. The puncture was caused by a drum cart while moving it onto a trailer in the 10-day transfer area at the Veolia office. The employees immediately noticed the leak and quickly set the drum down to keep it from leaking more by placing it on its side to prevent it from leaking further. The punctured drum was overpacked into an 851A2 salvage drum to continue transportation to the ultimate disposal facility. The drum leaked approximately 1/2 gallon of class 6.1 III waste Trichloroethylene. The liquid was cleaned up with spill pads and absorbent and the drum was over-packed into an appropriate 85 gallon salvage drum along with the clean up materials. The duration of release is anticipated to be about 1 minute due to the small hole and quick response. The drum was still substantially full after the leak occurred.

item.title: Report E-2023010113
item.description:
Report E-2023010113

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-01-06
  • City: MONTGOMERY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 0933 ET XPO Logistics terminal XNW notified ERTS of a UN3264 release from a 250-gallon tote due to a puncture from other freight during transit, impacting the trailer floor. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 25-gallons of product released to a 4' x 15' area of the trailer floor and a 3' x 10' area of the concrete lot below due to a puncture caused by wood. Absorbents were worked into the impacted areas and collected. The material was transferred into a new tote. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into four 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023020163
item.description:
Report E-2023020163

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-12-24
  • City: Jamaica
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: JETBLUE AIRWAYS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 24, 2022, at approximately 20:53 local time (01:53 UTC), N558JB, an Airbus A320 operating as scheduled Flight 662 from Bridgetown, Barbados (BGI) to New York, NY (JFK) experienced a Customer-initiated emergency evacuation due to a Lithium Ion Battery Thermal Runaway. While pulling into the gate, a battery charger belonging to the Customer seated in seat 8D appeared to be smoking. Once parked at the gate the flight crew began the emergency evacuation checklist, and made the "Cabin Crew at Stations" call, but did not give the "EASY VICTOR" command (the command to begin an evacuation). The Captain went back into the cabin and used a halon fire extinguisher and cold water to cool the unit down. Aircraft Rescue and Firefighting (ARFF) had been contacted and were on the jet bridge when the main boarding door was opened. Before the jet bridge was attached, Customers opened the over-wing emergency exit doors, apparently without instructions from the crew. Both the right and left doors were opened resulting in deployments of both over-wing slides. Approximately 63 Customers exited the aircraft via the slides with the remainder exiting the aircraft through the main boarding door and Jet Bridge. During an initial review of closed-circuit television footage from the gate area, it was noted that a large number of customers climbed out of the over-wing doors and went down the slides with large roller board or similar luggage in hand. There were no serious injuries reported among the 128 customers and 6 crewmembers. Three customers reportedly were evaluated by emergency medical personnel for smoke inhalation and two others for elbow pain. All five were cleared without further treatment. There was no significant damage reported to the aircraft. Tech Ops evaluated the aircraft and removed it from service.

  • Description: CORRUGATED BOX WITH WET BOTTOM DISCOVERED BY DMP RESPONDER DURING UNLOAD FROM PACKAGE VEHICLE. UPON INSPECTION, PACKAGE WAS DETERMINED TO HAVE BEEN WETTED FROM THE OUTSIDE DUE TO RAINSTORM. FUTHER INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS REVEALED THEY DID NOT MATCH OUTER CARTON DESCRIPTION. HAZMAT AUDITOR WAS BROUGHT IN TO EVALUATE CONTENTS AND DETERMINED THAT THE SHIPMENT REQUIRED AT A MINIMUM A UN1133 LABEL. AN SDS WAS OBTAINED DURING THE HAZMAT AUDIT, AND THE HAZMAT HELP DESK WAS COINTACTED FOR FURTHER INSTRUCTION. CONTENTS WERE TEMPORARILY RE-PACKAGED IN A NEW CORRUGATED BOX AND SET ASIDE FOR RECOVERY BY THE SHIPPER.

item.description:
Report E-2023010089

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-12-20
  • City: ELMSFORD
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 0858 ET, XPO Logistics terminal XEM called to report a 2.5-gallon release of UN3265 Spectrus NX1106 due to a pinhole puncture in a poly drum. The containers were refused by the customer due to the pinhole punctures and had been sitting in the OS&D bay since December 21th 2022. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment. Contractors arrived onsite and advised the three jugs had pinhole punctures, however there was no release at the time of the contractor’s response. Crew confirmed there was no product on the dock or pallet to clean. The damaged jugs were containerized into an 80-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023010022
item.description:
Report E-2023010022

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-12-08
  • City: SCHENECTADY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 12/08/2022 Veolia employees were loading drums into a trailer at the Veolia, Schenecady, NY facility when an employee noticed that a 55-gallon plastic drum was slightly leaking. It is assumed that another employee mistakenly punctured a 55 gallon plastic drum when it was being loaded onto the trailer the day before. The drum was placed immediately on its side to prevent it from leaking further and then was overpacked into an 851A2 salvage drum to continue transportation to the ultimate disposal facility. The drum leaked about 1/2 gallon of class 9 material with waste chromium solution. The liquid was cleaned up with spill pads and absorbent and the drum was overpacked into an appropriate 85 gallon salvage drum along with the clean up materials. The duration of release is anticipated to be about 24 hours but due to the small hole, only about 1/2 a gallon leaked. The drum was still substantially full when the leak was discovered. On 12/08/2022 the Veolia safety manager was notified and an investigation was performed. The results of the investigation revealed that a newer employee was assisting another employee with the shipment. The trailer was being filled with containers and the employee was not immediately aware that they had poked a hole in the drum until notified the following day by Veolia EHS.

item.title: Report I-2022120290
item.description:
Report I-2022120290

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-11-02
  • City: Jamaica
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: ALLIANCE GROUND INTERNATIONAL,
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While loading freight, drum was punctured by a forklift, which resulted in the loss of approximately 50 gallons of free product to the asphalt/concrete surface at loading area. Alliance Ground International applied absorbent material to contain the free product to immediate area, Miller Environmental Group was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, Miller Environmental offloaded the skid and found the damaged drum. Damaged drum was overpacked and additional absorbent material was applied to the impacted impervious surface. Miller Environmental proceeded to recover the impacted absorbents, break down contaminated skid, and containerized all spent absorbents and cleanup debris into 5 55-gallon drums. Disposal will be coordinated in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There was no impact to surface soils or threat to enter state waters. Free product was contained to an impervious surface and recovered without further incident. There were no injuries or exposures.

item.title: Report X-2022110793
item.description:
Report X-2022110793

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-11-08
  • City: BUFFALO
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: On 11/07/2022 between 6:20pm and 6:30pm, Outbound sort manager called QA over radio to notify us that there was a leaking Hazmat package in delivery vehicle in work area 1016. QA removed damaged package from delivery vehicle, placed in proper Hazmat bin and staged in hazmat cage for future processing. After package was staged in Hazmat Cage, QA notified Pickup and delivery management of the situation via Email. Package was inspected by QA on 11/08/2022 to determine damage. It was discovered that one metal can of Certified Mile-Hi with Octane Boost Gasoline improver was dented and leaking contents. Only one can was damaged out of the six total in the package. Upon inspection of the packaging it was discovered that contents were not shipped in regulated fiberboard box. Damaged package Report was completed on 11/08/2022 and QA is currently awaiting further instructions on how to proceed. DescribePack: Top and side of body of can dented. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Upon notification of leakage, package was retrieved and staged in Fedex Ground regulated bin for leaking Hazmat. Due to size of packaging, QA had to open package and remove all six cans and place them in bin. Packaging was kept together with cans. Leaking fluid cleaned with absorbent pads. Contents then placed in hazmat cage under ventilation. P&D management then notified via Email of situation.

item.description:
Report E-2022110517

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-10-25
  • City: ALBANY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. E-2022110517 On October 25, 2022, at 0410 ET, XPO Logistics Terminal XAB, experienced a UN2014 “Puracil Purashock” release from a box containing four 1-gallon poly bottles due to improper loading. No soils, drains, or waterways were reported to have been impacted. ERTS dispatched Hepaco to conduct all on site cleanup activities. 2. E-2022110530On October 25, 2022, at 0705 EST, Hepaco arrived on site and confirmed approximately 1-quart of product released from a box containing four 1-gallon poly bottles. The material impacted the packaging only due to a leaking cap. Four of the jugs were containerized into a 25-gallon poly drum. All impacted absorbents, cardboard, and cleanup debris were placed into a 10-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2022110370
item.description:
Report E-2022110370

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-10-22
  • City: Buffalo
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 10/22/2022, at 1013 hours, personnel in the CSXT Frontier Yard discovered UTLX 206651, a loaded tank car of Fuel Oil, leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and the shipper of record, National Response Center, and New York Department of Environmental Conservation were notified. (CHEMTREC Report #2022-1022-00112). Marion Environmental, Inc, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found multiple manway cover bolts less than tool tight, resulting in a release of lading. The issue was identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper of record, it was determined the offeror of the car was Petroleum Services Corporation, phone 412.420.4076. Contractor personnel secured all manway cover bolts in accordance with 49 CFR 173.31 and cleaned all impacted car surfaces. The leak was secured and the car was released for transport. This incident did not require a special switching move. 7.1 is not required. Cause Code: 200 NARRI: 60

  • Description: XPO Terminal XAB contacted ERTS to report a 55-gallon spill of regulated UN3082 "Dolphon CC-1105" that was released from one 55-gallon metal drum. Mr. Brooks stated that the spill impacted the inside of Trailer #3192774. ERTS and the caller reviewed the MSDS. Due to the amount released, Mr. Brooks requested that ERTS dispatch a contractor complete the clean-up activity. ERTS dispatched a network contractor who confirmed the report details. All waste has been left onsite for XPO to manage through their waste stream.

item.title: Report I-2022120016
item.description:
Report I-2022120016

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-07
  • City: BUFFALO
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Buffalo Southern Railroad, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While a Buffalo Southern RR (BSOR) conductor was preparing a string of cars to be moved at BC Yard in Buffalo, he observed that a hissing sound coming from the manway atop tank car CGTX 65310. He notified the remaining crew to remain in the locomotive and await further instruction. This was at approximately 15: 15 hrs. The conductor notified a senior BSOR employee of the situation and a call was place at approximately 15:22 to Patrick Connors, CMO and train operation manager. A call was also placed to Steve Meyers, FRA for guidance. It was decided to have the conductor call the Chemtrec emergency response center. (Chemtrec Report #2022090706314) Patrick Connors began making calls to BSOR management and the shipper to begin a response plan, as well as the NRC and NYSDOT. Delays in making direct contact to the shipper resulted in a decision being made to contact a contractor to respond immediately to the location. A call was placed to the Norfolk Southern Yardmaster and MTO to alert them of the situation and its location. Train operations were halted on the adjoining track. The contractor arrived at the location at approximately 17:20. The contractor metered the air quality and inspected the car. They opened the protective housing lid and found the 8-side liquid line frozen with a visible vapor leak of propane. they also observed the secondary plug on the liquid line was not tool-tight, with peeling thread tape. They tightened the plug, but noticed the leak did not cease even after being tool-tight. They then relieved plug pressure by purging frozen materials, and resealed the valve. and at 18:30 noted the leak had ceased. At 1845 hrs, the wiped down the plug and valve threads, applied new thread tape to the secondary plug and used a Multi-Rae multi meter and soapy water solution to verify that the valve was closed. Pat Connors of the BSOR called all the contacted parties to advise them of the containment of the release. The NS was contacted to allow for the resumption of their train operations.

item.title: Report X-2022100799
item.description:
Report X-2022100799

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-28
  • City: WEST HENRIETTA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Wet package was found at unload by a manager at 7:15am. Area was cleared by the manager who then called QA. QA looked up the sds based on the visible UN number. QA gathered ppe based on SDS placed in Hazmat drum in the hazmat cage and then scanned it 39 upon examination. Drum was resealed and placed under vent fan after ISF and DPRs with used PPE enclosed. DescribePack: The package contained 4-1 gallon bottles of Muriatic Acid (UN1789), one of which had a loose cap and well as a failed seal beneath the loose cap. Box was wet but luckily it didn't spill onto other packages. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Area was cleared by Manager who discovered the package. Package was not moved until QA was able to get proper PPE. Hazmat was sealed in Yellow HazMat bin and placed under vent fan.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Pkg was found on the trailer and came in damaged. The box was open and soaked. There was one bottle that leaked a small amount of fluid out. I believe there should be 2 more gallons in this package but there as only 2 not 4. Package says it weighed 41.60lbs. 2 gallons do not add up to that weight. I think 2 bottles may be back in the previous station they never made it to this station. No one found these bottles on the truck. I am not sure if there was 4 for sure but the weight is off by almost half what it should be so it leads m to believe this was damaged in the last station and the missing bottles may be there. For now the package and contents are in a bin in the hazmat cage waiting for the disposition and verification. DescribePack: Box ripped open, possible lost bottles. 1 cap loose on one of the bottles. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Brought to hazmat cage immediately and inspected. Contents were but in a hazmat bin .

  • Description: On September 28, 2022, one (1) 330-gallon tote of hydrofluoric acid fell off of a lift grate and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the asphalt parking lot. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to perform the necessary corrective actions. MEG personnel utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted surface and containerized all impacted-material into four (4) 35-gallon drums. MEG then transferred the remaining contents of the damaged tote into one (1) 275-gallon tote and one (1) 35-gallon poly drum.

item.title: Report X-2022090932
item.description:
Report X-2022090932

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-07
  • City: HOLBROOK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The driver carried the Hazmat box to the recipients door. When he was approaching he heard some drips. He turned the box to see under it and the bottom opened up causing the four gallons and one empty spray bottle to fall out. He immediately turned the box upside down and reloaded the 4 gallon containers into the upside down box. He obtained a plastic container from his truck and loaded the upside down box, with the gallon containers upright, into the plastic container. He drove the container back to the warehouse not leaking. He handed to QA and let QA know what happened. DescribePack: The 1 gallon container had a loose cap and the foil seal was open. This caused the container to leak quickly when the driver looked under the box to see why he saw some drips. By now the bottom of the container had the isopropanol on it and the bottom of the fiberboard box got weak and broke open. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The driver turned the box upside down and reloaded the 4 gallon containers into the upside down box. He stood the gallon containers upright to stop the leak.

item.title: Report I-2022100117
item.description:
Report I-2022100117

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-08-16
  • City: BRONX
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: on a slight incline. Instead of the pallet moving forward, the pallet jack rolled backwards. The driver d not have the rear Iiftgate flap in the raised position. Therefore, the pallet jack fell off the lift gate backwards spilling the pallet of junk batteries. Approximately 54 batteries fell off the pallet on to the pavement. Battery caps fell off approximately 4 batteries resulting in a small release of battery acid onto the street. No storm drains were affected. The NAPA employees on site cleaned up the spilled battery acid. The spent batteries were checked for Ieakage and restacked. The Ieaking batteries were put into plastic bags with speedy dry. The non-Ieaking batteries were wiped off and re-palletized. All batteries were returned to East Penn Manufacturing Co., Lyon Station to be recycled at our secondary lead smelter.

  • City: MELVILLE

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: On July 28 at approximately 0945 the sort facility at FRGA was notified of a spill. A FedEx box containing approximately thirteen - one pound bags of Clorox Pool & Spa Shock XtraBlue was found to be leaking a small amount of the powder from the damaged corners of the package. A strong chlorine order was also emanating from the package. There were no markings or labels indicating that this was UN1759 Corrosive Solid, n.o.s. (Sodium dichloro-s-triazinetrione, copper compounds), 8, PGIII. DG admin asked that the package be put in a salvage drum and held until further notice.

THERE WAS A BAG AROUND THE BOTTLE WHICH CONTAINED THE CRYSTALIZED LIQUID SO NONE OF IT LEAKED FROM THE PACKAGE. I SEEN NO DAMAGE AT ALL TO THE BOX HOLDING THE PACKAGE. I DID MY REPORTS AND THEN CONTAINED THIS INSIDE OF THE HAZMAT BIN. DescribePack: THE GLASS BOTTLE CONTAINING THE LIQUID WAS BROKEN. NO OUTER DAMAGE TO THE BOX IT WAS IN. THERE WAS A BAG AROUND THE BOTTLE WHICH CONTAINED THE LEAK DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: IMMEDIATELY BROUGHT TO HAZMAT CAGE, INSPECTED AND PUT INSIDE A HAZMAT BIN UNDER THE FANS.

  • City: BINGHAMTON

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 15, 2022, at 0910 EST, XPO Logistics Terminal XBH experienced the release of UN1791 “San-I-King #451” from a 55 gallon poly drum due to a forklift puncture. ERTS dispatched Miller Environmental to conduct all onsite cleanup and overpacking operations. On July 15, 2022, at 1430 EST, Miller Environmental personnel arrived on site and confirmed approximately 5 gallons of product released to a 60’ x 8’ area of the trailer and dock floor. The damaged drum was placed into a 95 gallon poly over pack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted areas and then collected into a 55 gallon poly drum. All waste was left on site for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: PACKAGE WAS LOADED FOR TRANSPORT AND OUT FOR DELIVERY. PACKAGE HAD PREVIOUSLY BEEN SENT OUT FOR DELIVERY BUT THE RECIEVER WAS CLOSED AT ATTEMPT. PACKAGE DID NOT GO OUT FOR DELIVERY. RECIEVER WAS DETERMINED TO BE CLOSED FOR HOLIDAY AND THE PACKAGE DID NOT LEAVE THE FACILITY. THE PACKAGE WAS RECORDED AS REFUSED BY THE RECIEVER. PACKAGE WAS WRAPPED IN 4 DRIVER RELEASE BAGS DO TO SPILLAGE. THE PACKAGE WAS LEFT AT THE DMP LATER THAT DAY. MOST OF THE LABELING HAD BEEN DESTROYED DO TO THE VAPORS AND SPILLAGE.

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: RESPONDED TO A PACKAGE THAT WAS COLD TO THE TOUCH. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED FIVE NON REGULATED FROZEN ULINE COLD PACKS BUT UNDERNEATH THERE WERE PIECES OF DRY ICE. THE COLD PACKS AND DRY ICE ARE COOLING A SMALL BAG WHICH CONTAINS 4 SMALL PLASTIC CONTAINERS OF TISSUE SPECIMENS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX INDICATING DRY ICE IS BEING USED. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report E-2022060656
item.description:
Report E-2022060656

Identified by scraper @ 2023-05-16T18:11:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-06-15
  • City: COLONIE
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EQ NORTHEAST, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The packages are generally designed to be lifted from the top of the package. In this case, they were being transported by a van trailer and were placed onto a pallet. The pallet chosen was not sturdy enough to fully support the bag, and there were large spaces between the slats on the pallet. The weight of the bag crushed down parts of the pallet, and caused sections of the bag to sag into the void space between the pallet slats, down into the space used to move the pallet. When the forklift was used to lift the pallet, the forks punctured the bag, causing the release. The pallet and bag were placed into a temporary containment and an inhouse response team was called in to repackage the contents into drums.

  • Description: On June 8, 2022, one (1) 18-gallon drum containing corrosive liquid (phosphoric and citric acid) was punctured by a skid during transit and released approximately sixteen (16) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC, who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to perform the necessary corrective action. ES personnel drummed the damaged container, then utilized sodium bicarbonate and absorbents to remediate the impacted surface.
